case_vignette:
A 35-year-old construction worker presents with a well-circumscribed, verrucous plaque on his left upper arm. The lesion has been present for a few months, but recently has increased in size and become painful. He reports that a cough preceded his skin lesion, but otherwise has no relevant medical history. A large verrucous and ulcerating lesion with pustules is seen. On palpation, a purulent discharge is expressed. The patient is a 35-year-old construction worker.

question: What is the final diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Dermatology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask only one question at a time, and it should not be more than 1 line. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. Do not ask the same question multiple times. Ask different questions to cover more information. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain, only give the diagnosis name. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized. You must give only 1 diagnosis otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I have a painful, rough-textured skin bump on my left upper arm that has grown bigger recently, and it started shortly after I had a cough a few months ago.
Have you noticed any color changes or bleeding in the bump?
No, there are no color changes or bleeding, but the bump is now ulcerating and has pus-filled bumps on it.
Do you have any other medical conditions or are you currently taking any medications?
No, I don't have any other medical conditions and I'm not taking any medications.
Has anyone in your family had similar skin issues or any history of skin cancer?
No, there's no family history of similar skin issues or skin cancer.
Has the bump been exposed to the sun or any chemicals frequently?
I work in construction, so it might have been exposed to some chemicals, but I'm not sure about frequent sun exposure specifically to that area.
Final Diagnosis: Squamous Cell Carcinoma.

trial_0.summarized_conversation: A patient reports a painful, rough-textured skin bump on their left upper arm that has recently increased in size. The bump appeared shortly after the patient experienced a cough a few months ago. The patient notes that the bump does not show any changes in color or bleeding but mentions that it is now ulcerating and has developed pus-filled bumps. The patient confirms having no other medical conditions and is currently not on any medications. There is no family history of similar skin issues or skin cancer. The patient works in construction, which may have involved exposure to chemicals, although the patient is uncertain about the frequency of sun exposure specifically to the affected area.
trial_0.summarized_frq: The final diagnosis is likely to be a cutaneous infection, possibly due to exposure to chemicals or environmental irritants in the construction work setting, complicated by a secondary bacterial infection leading to pus formation and ulceration.
